intro: Eryngium kotschyi, commonly known as the Persian sea holly, is a flowering plant native to the Middle East and parts of Central Asia. It is characterized by its spiky, blue or purple flower heads that resemble a sea urchin, surrounded by silver-gray bracts. The plant typically grows in rocky or arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. Its leaves are usually lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its drought-resistant nature. Eryngium kotschyi is valued in horticulture for its ornamental appeal and ability to thrive in well-drained soils.
